newsitem.title: UK: Euromarkets ignore Iraq raid, Wall St fall.
newsitem.headline: Euromarkets ignore Iraq raid, Wall St fall.

text.p: European financial markets took news of a second U.S. strike on Iraq in their stride on Wednesday, with stocks trading stronger, gold weaker, and the dollar rock steady.
The bourses shrugged off Wall Street's weak opening to trade steady at the higher levels established earlier on Wednesday.

British shares, which had been buoyed by New York's reversal from slump to 30-point gain on Tuesday, took the Dow's opening falls calmy, and traded around 20 points ahead, not far from their best 23-point gain.
An agreed 264 million pound ($412.1 million) bid by food distributor Booker for food wholesaler Nurdin & Peacock also helped sentiment, sending the blue chip FTSE 100 index up 25 points.
Traders said the London market was likely to be quiet because of a monetary meeting between Governor of the Bank of England Eddie George and finance minister Kenneth Clarke.
German shares ended their bourse session up 21 points, but the electronically traded IBIS DAX was down around two points.
Dealers said that trade was likely to be steady, but the focus was definitely on key U.S. non-farm payroll data for August due on Friday, which could set the tone for U.S. interest rates.
In Paris, French stocks traded around 15 points higher, helped by firmer bond prices ignoring Wall Street's opening dips.

Oil stocks Total and Elf-Aquitaine, which have risen on the back of higher oil prices, extended their gains after Total confirmed investor expectations of good results by reporting a 45 percent jump in its first-half profit.
In currencies, the dollar was off its highs against the mark and off its earlier lows against the yen in lacklustre trade in the European afternoon.

Dealers said market attention had shifted from the U.S. attacks in Iraq to Thursday's German GDP data and, more importantly, Friday's U.S. jobs figures against a backdrop of growing expectations of higher U.S. rates near-term.

"It's a waiting game now until Friday, no one's willing to stick their neck out ahead of the payrolls," said a dealer at a U.S. bank here. "The Iraq story is still there but it's been moved very much to the background now."
CURRENCIES AT 1430 GMT
The dollar was trading at 1.4840 marks and 108.75 yen after 1.4837 marks and 109.25 yen on Tuesday.
STOCK MARKETS AT 1430 GMT
The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading British shares was up 17.1 points at 3,873.0.
Frankfurt's 30-share DAX index was 21.16 up at 2,532.37. The IBIS DAX was down 2.96 at 2,525.77.
In Paris, the CAC-40 share index was up 10.68 at 1,982.33.
PRECIOUS METALS
Gold fixed easier at $385.60 vs $385.95 this morning and $386.60 Tuesday afternoon.
